newsitem.title: LUXEMBOURG: Court finds Germany late to enact rules on poultry.
newsitem.headline: Court finds Germany late to enact rules on poultry.

text.p: The European Court of Justice found on Thursday Germany was late to enact Community rules on the health problems arising from poultry meat.
The German government did not contest the infingement but argued the lateness did not obstruct Community trade and that national legislation was pending.
The court maintained its strict adherence to prescribed time periods set out in Community directives and found Germany failed to fulfil its member state obligations.
"Failure of a member state to fulfil its obligations - Directve 92/116/EEC - Failure to transpose within the prescribed period"

application for a declaration that, by failing to adopt within the prescibed period the laws, regulations and administrative provisions necessary to comply with Council directive 92/116/EEC amending and updating directive 71/118/EEC on health problems affecting trade in fresh poultrymeat (OJ 1993 L 62, p. 1), the Federal Republic of Germany has failed to fulfil its obligations under that directive and the EC treaty

1. Declares that, by failing to adopt within the prescibed period the laws, regulations and administrative provisions necessary to comply with Council directive 92/116/EEC amending and updating directive 71/118/EEC on health problems affecting trade in fresh poultrymeat, the Federal Republic of Germany has failed to fulfil its obligations under that directive and the EC treaty;
2. Orders Federal Republic of Germany to pay the costs.
